div.p: Two-dimensional CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models are used to compare the behavior of different cooling techniques on the lattice. Cooling is one of the most frequently used tools to study on the lattice the topological properties of the vacuum of a field theory. We show that different cooling methods behave in an equivalent way. To see this we apply the cooling methods on classical instantonic configurations and on configurations of the thermal equilibrium ensemble. We also calculate the topological susceptibility by using the cooling technique.

p.span: Partially supported by MURST and by EC TMR program ERBFMRX-CT97-0122.

div.p: Twoâ€“dimensional (2d) CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} modelsÂ [1, 2] play an important role in quantum field theory since they represent a convenient theoretical laboratory to investigate analytical and numerical methods to be eventually exported to QCD. This is believed to be possible since these models have several important properties in common with QCD, for instance asymptotic freedom, spontaneous mass generation, confinement and topological structure of the vacuumÂ [3]. In particular, the CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} vacuum, like the QCD one, admits instanton classical solutions. The nonâ€“trivial structure of the vacuum for the CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, as well as for QCD, can be probed by defining suitable operators, like the topological charge density and its correlators, and by applying the prescriptions of quantum field theory. Yet most of the observables relevant for the investigation of the vacuum topological structure of a theory are beyond the reach of perturbation theory. Therefore some approximation is needed which works also in the nonâ€“perturbative regime. So far, the most effective and comprehensive tool is represented by Monte Carlo simulations on a spaceâ€“time lattice. The lattice approach for the study of the vacuum structure brings about a very delicate task, that of separating the quantum fluctuations at the level of the lattice spacing from the relevant longâ€“distance topological ones in any given configuration of the thermal equilibrium ensemble. Indeed, trying to assign a topological charge to a thermal equilibrium configuration, treating on the same footing shortâ€“distance (quantum) fluctuations and longâ€“distance (topological) ones, would even prevent the reaching of the continuum limit. One powerful technique, frequently adopted in the literature to study the topological structure of the vacuum, is the soâ€“called cooling methodÂ [4]. The idea behind the cooling method is that the quantum fluctuations at the level of the lattice spacing of a given configuration can be smoothed out by a sequence of local minimizations of the lattice action, thus leading to a configuration where only the longâ€“distance, topologically relevant fluctuations survive. When this procedure is performed on a set of wellâ€“decorrelated equilibrium configurations, it yields a â€œcooledâ€ equilibrium ensemble on which the expectation values of topological quantities can be determined. The precise definition of a cooling procedure is however arbitrary to a large extent: the lattice action to be locally minimized can be chosen differently from the one used in the thermalization, the number of cooling steps is a free variable, driving or control parameters of the cooling can be introduced, and so on. Comparing the behavior of different cooling methods is an interesting issue, especially when a new cooling strategy is proposed.

The aim of the present work is to get insight into a new cooling method first adopted in Ref.Â [5] for the SU(2) gauge theory and to compare it with two other methods, already known in the literature, namely the â€œstandardâ€Â [4] cooling and its controlled version adopted by the Pisa group (see for instance Ref.Â [6]). The new cooling method, as it will be pointed out in the next Section, follows a different strategy with respect to the other two and could possess various interesting features, inaccessible to the other two cooling methods, like for instance preserving instantonâ€“anti-instanton (Iâ€“A) pairs with interaction energy smaller than a fixable valueÂ [5]. The testâ€“field for this comparison will be provided by the CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, which have all the interesting topological properties of the SU(Nğ‘italic-NN) gauge theories, but are much easier to simulate on a lattice.

The paper is organized as follows: in SectionÂ 2 we introduce the lattice action and the lattice discretization of the relevant topological quantities. In SectionÂ 3 we describe in detail the three cooling methods. In SectionsÂ 4 and 5 we discuss their performance on 1â€“instanton and Iâ€“A classical lattice configurations respectively. In SectionÂ 6 we consider their behavior on thermal equilibrium configurations and find a correspondence between the three cooling techniques. In SectionÂ 7 we determine the physical value of the topological susceptibility of CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} using the new cooling method and compare the results to those from an alternative approach not based on cooling. Finally in SectionÂ 8 we draw our conclusions.

The extraction of Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi from the lattice thus requires the determination of both the multiplicative and additive renormalizations, Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta). This is a feasible task, as will be shown in SectionÂ 7, and in this way one obtains the soâ€“called â€œfield theoreticalâ€ determination of the topological susceptibility.

Alternatively one can use cooling to determine the topological susceptibility. This method will be described extensively in the next Section. The idea is that, by an iterative process of local minimization of the action, the quantum fluctuations at the scale of the ultraviolet cutâ€“off, which are responsible for the renormalizations, are suppressed thus implying Zâ†’1â†’ğ‘1italic-Z ARROW:to NUMBER:1Z\to 1 and Mâ†’0â†’ğ‘€0italic-M ARROW:to NUMBER:0M\to 0 in Eq.Â (10) as the cooling iteration goes on, so that a2â¢Ï‡superscriptğ‘2ğœ’italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chia^{2}\,\chi can be extracted directly from the measurement of Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} after cooling, as it will be shown in SectionÂ 7.

A cooling step applied on a lattice configuration consists in assigning to every field variable a new value chosen in order to locally minimize the lattice action. The iteration of this procedure converges to a configuration which should represent a solution of the Euclidean classical equations of motion. In the continuum 2d CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, as well as in the case of 4d SU(Nğ‘italic-NN) gauge theories, there are classical solutions that belong to a definite topological charge sector, identified by an integer value of the topological charge Qğ‘„italic-QQ and by a finite action (S=2â¢Ï€â¢|Q|/gğ‘†2ğœ‹ğ‘„ğ‘”italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi VERTBAR:| italic-Q VERTBAR:| MULOP:divide italic-gS=2\pi|Q|/g in the case of CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1}). The classical solutions with Qâ‰ 0ğ‘„0italic-Q RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0Q\neq 0 are called instantons or anti-instantons (depending on the sign of Qğ‘„italic-QQ). On the lattice, owing to the artifacts introduced by the discretization of the theory, configurations with nonâ€“trivial topology can represent only approximated solutions of the lattice equations of motion. The common belief is that a moderately long cooling sequence can be able to wash out the quantum fluctuations of a given lattice configuration, so revealing the underlying metastable state with possible nonâ€“trivial topology, and that this state is the lattice counterpart of a continuum classical one. Of course, if the cooling is further protracted, the metastable state will eventually â€œdecayâ€ into the trivial vacuum. Stated in other words, once the quantum fluctuations have been eliminated and the topological bumps of a configuration (instantons or anti-instantons) have been revealed, if the cooling is further protracted then the isolated instantons or anti-instantons shrink, the Iâ€“A pairs annihilate and the configuration falls into the trivial vacuum of the lattice theory. In consideration of the above arguments, it is clear that a great care is needed in determining when a cooling iteration has to be stopped. Nevertheless, there is no way to prevent the loss of topological signal at lattice scales of the order of the lattice spacing, since topology at these scales cannot be distinguished from quantum fluctuations. It must be pointed out however, that any loss of topological signal due to cooling which occurs at fixed scales in lattice units becomes irrelevant in physical units as far as the coupling is tuned towards its critical value, i.e. in the continuum limit, when the lattice spacing ağ‘italic-aa tends to zero. This is not the case only when the instanton size distribution is singular in the shortâ€“distance regime, as in the 2d CP11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1} modelÂ [11, 12].

In the case of the 2d CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, the cooling algorithm amounts to replacing at each lattice site xğ‘¥italic-xx the field variables zâ¢(x)ğ‘§ğ‘¥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and Î»Î¼â¢(x)subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) by new ones znewâ¢(x)superscriptğ‘§newğ‘¥italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z^{\mathrm{new}}(x) and Î»Î¼newâ¢(x)superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğœ‡newğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x), chosen in order to locally minimize the lattice action, while the other field variables are left unchanged. A cooling step consists in a sweep through the entire lattice volume in order to apply this local minimization sequentially at every site xğ‘¥italic-xx. The terms in the action density which depend on zâ¢(x)ğ‘§ğ‘¥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and Î»Î¼â¢(x)subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) for a given lattice site xğ‘¥italic-xx have the form

According to the supplementary conditions under which the above replacements are performed, we have different cooling procedures. The first cooling procedure, which we call â€œstandardâ€, is the one where the replacements zâ¢(x)â†’znewâ¢(x)â†’ğ‘§ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘§newğ‘¥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ARROW:rightarrow italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x)\rightarrow z^{\mathrm{new}}(x) and Î»Î¼â¢(x)â†’Î»Î¼newâ¢(x)â†’subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğœ‡newğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ARROW:rightarrow italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x)\rightarrow\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x) are unconstrained. The second one, which we call â€œPisa coolingâ€, is the one where the replacement of zâ¢(x)ğ‘§ğ‘¥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and Î»Î¼â¢(x)subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) is performed if the distance between the old and the new fields is smaller than a previously fixed parameter Î´Pisasubscriptğ›¿Pisaitalic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{\rm Pisa}: ||Î»Î¼â¢(x)-Î»Î¼newâ¢(x)||â‰¤Î´Pisanormsubscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğœ‡newğ‘¥subscriptğ›¿PisaVERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end||\lambda_{\mu}(x)-\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x)||\leq\delta_{\rm Pisa} and analogously for the zğ‘§italic-zz fields, otherwise the new field is chosen to lie on the (zâ¢(x),znewâ¢(x))ğ‘§ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘§newğ‘¥OPEN:( italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:)(z(x),z^{\mathrm{new}}(x)) ((Î»Î¼â¢(x),Î»Î¼newâ¢(x))subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğœ‡newğ‘¥OPEN:( italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start new POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:)(\lambda_{\mu}(x),\lambda_{\mu}^{\mathrm{new}}(x))) plane, at a distance from zâ¢(x)ğ‘§ğ‘¥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) (Î»Î¼â¢(x)subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x)) exactly equal to Î´Pisasubscriptğ›¿Pisaitalic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{\rm Pisa}Â [6]. The third cooling procedure, called â€œnew coolingâ€ in the following, was introduced in Ref.Â [5]. It consists in making the replacement only if the distance between the old and new fields is larger than a fixed parameter Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta, otherwise the field is left unchanged. We observe that the three methods follow a different strategy. In particular, while the Pisa cooling acts first on the smoother fluctuations and the number of cooling iterations to be performed has to be fixed a priori, the new cooling performs local minimizations only if these fluctuations are larger than a given threshold and the iteration stops automatically when all the surviving fluctuations are smoother than the (lattice) threshold determined by the dimensionless parameter Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta. It is easy to see that the new field variables differ from the old ones by terms which, in the continuum limit, are of order a2superscriptğ‘2italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:enda^{2}, where ağ‘italic-aa is the lattice spacing. Therefore the parameter Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta is expected to scale in the continuum limit like a quantity of dimension two.

div.p: In the following we will compare these three cooling methods in several contexts, namely on â€œartificialâ€ 1â€“instanton configurations, on Iâ€“A pairs, on thermal equilibrium configurations and in the determination of the continuum topological susceptibility. Moreover we will establish a relation between the number of cooling iterations in the standard and Pisa coolings with the parameter Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta of the new cooling and will discuss the validity of the picture of cooling as a diffusion process.

In the continuum CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} models, in the infinite 2d spaceâ€“time, a 1â€“instanton configuration is a classical solution of the equations of motion characterized by a topological charge one and a finite action (S=2â¢Ï€/gğ‘†2ğœ‹ğ‘”italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-gS=2\pi/g). The explicit form of a continuum 1â€“instanton configuration is

Actually 1â€“instanton configurations cannot exist on a 2d torus even in the continuumÂ [13] and they represent only approximate solutions of the classical equations of motion. This approximation becomes better and better as the ratio Ï/(Lâ¢a)ğœŒğ¿ğ‘italic-rho MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-L italic-a CLOSE:)\rho/(La) decreases. On the lattice, this problem would lead to metastability even in the case of an ideally perfect discretization. However the aboveâ€“defined artificial 1â€“instanton lattice configurations are enough for our purposes since they will be used only as test configurations for cooling methods and not to extract physical information.

These angles are defined as

div.p: It is clear that, while the standard cooling acts indistinctly on each lattice site, the Pisa cooling and the new cooling deform 1â€“instanton lattice configurations starting from different regions of the lattice. The new cooling will act first on the region around the center of the instanton, the Pisa cooling on the border regions. Therefore it is not obvious whether under the three coolings the configurations will look the same sweep after sweep. We did therefore the following check: we performed a long (Oâ¢(1000)ğ‘‚1000italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1000 CLOSE:)O(1000) steps) iteration of the standard and Pisa coolings111For the Pisa cooling we always use Î´Pisa=0.2subscriptğ›¿Pisa0.2italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2\delta_{\rm Pisa}=0.2, following Ref.Â [14]. on an artificial 1â€“instanton configuration with size Ï=10â¢ağœŒ10ğ‘italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 italic-a\rho=10a and after each sweep we extracted the topological charge QLsuperscriptğ‘„ğ¿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L}, the action SLsuperscriptğ‘†ğ¿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} and the size Ï/ağœŒğ‘italic-rho MULOP:divide italic-a\rho/a. This size was determined by a very local procedure, namely by looking for the maximum of the lattice action density smaxLsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ¿maxitalic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends^{L}_{\mathrm{max}} and using the relation smaxL=2â¢a2/Ï2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ¿max2superscriptğ‘2superscriptğœŒ2italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{L}_{\mathrm{max}}=2a^{2}/\rho^{2}, valid for a 1â€“instanton configuration. Then, starting from the same configuration, we applied the new cooling for Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta as small as 5Ã—10-45superscript104NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-4} and for each configuration obtained during the cooling iteration, we determined again QLsuperscriptğ‘„ğ¿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L}, SLsuperscriptğ‘†ğ¿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} and Ï/ağœŒğ‘italic-rho MULOP:divide italic-a\rho/a. Finally, we put on a plot QLsuperscriptğ‘„ğ¿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L} and SLsuperscriptğ‘†ğ¿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} as functions of Ï/ağœŒğ‘italic-rho MULOP:divide italic-a\rho/a. The result is shown in Fig.Â 2: the values of QLsuperscriptğ‘„ğ¿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L} and SLsuperscriptğ‘†ğ¿italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{L} during the three cooling methods lie on the same curve. The same plot was obtained by using a different procedure to determine the size of the cooled configurations, namely a global fit of the lattice action density to the continuum expression for the action density of a 1â€“instanton configuration, Eq.Â (14). We interpret these results as an indication that the three coolings deformed in the same way the starting configuration. If this conjecture is correct, it should be possible to put into correspondence the Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta parameter of the new cooling with the number of steps of the standard or Pisa coolings. This will be done in SectionÂ 6.

div.p: where ci(I,A)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ¼ğ´italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I PUNCT:, italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc_{i}^{(I,A)} is the iğ‘–italic-iiâ€“th coordinate of the center of the instanton or anti-instanton and Ï(I,A)superscriptğœŒğ¼ğ´italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I PUNCT:, italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho^{(I,A)} are their sizes. As â€œartificialâ€ Iâ€“A lattice configuration we took the discretization of the above continuum configuration on a 2d finite volume lattice with periodic boundary conditions. For simplicity, we used Ï(I)=Ï(A)â‰¡ÏsuperscriptğœŒğ¼superscriptğœŒğ´ğœŒitalic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-rho\rho^{(I)}=\rho^{(A)}\equiv\rho.

Starting from several Iâ€“A pairs with different values of the distance between the centers c(I)superscriptğ‘ğ¼italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(I)} and c(A)superscriptğ‘ğ´italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(A)} and of the size ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho, we performed long cooling sequences with the three methods, namely Oâ¢(1000)ğ‘‚1000italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1000 CLOSE:)O(1000) iterations for the standard and Pisa coolings and Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta as small as 5Ã—10-45superscript104NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-4} for the new cooling. In order to have an indication of how the cooling process works, we examined by eye the distribution of the topological charge and action densities during the different cooling iterations. The evolution of these densities looked the same, no matter which cooling procedure was adopted. Specifically, the distribution of the action density shows at the beginning two equal instanton bumps, which for dâ‰«Ïmuch-greater-thanğ‘‘ğœŒitalic-d RELOP:much-greater-than italic-rhod\gg\rho (dğ‘‘italic-dd is the distance between the two centers c(I)superscriptğ‘ğ¼italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(I)} and c(A)superscriptğ‘ğ´italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{(A)}) are wellâ€“separated; then, as the cooling goes on, these bumps lower in height and merge together, up to complete annihilation. In order to make quantitative the statement that the three coolings behave essentially in the same way, we studied the shell correlation function of the topological charge density. This function is defined as Gâ¢(r)â‰¡1/Nrâ¢âˆ‘x,yqLâ¢(x)â¢qLâ¢(y)ğºğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘ğ¿ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘ğ¿ğ‘¦italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:){G}(r)\equiv 1/N_{r}\sum_{x,y}q^{L}(x)q^{L}(y) where the sum is extended over all pairs of sites xğ‘¥italic-xx, yğ‘¦italic-yy which satisfy râ‰¤|x-y|<r+Î”â¢rğ‘Ÿğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ŸÎ”ğ‘Ÿitalic-r RELOP:less-than-or-equals VERTBAR:| italic-x ADDOP:minus italic-y VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than italic-r ADDOP:plus Delta italic-rr\leq|x-y|<r+\Delta\,r and Nrsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{r} is the number of those pairs for a given value of rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr (we have chosen Î”â¢r=0.6â¢aÎ”ğ‘Ÿ0.6ğ‘Delta italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.6 italic-a\Delta\,r=0.6\,a). We determined Gâ¢(r)ğºğ‘Ÿitalic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:){G}(r) on every configuration resulting after each cooling iteration222From reflection positivity it follows that the twoâ€“point correlation function of the topological charge density, and consequently also âŸ¨Gâ¢(r)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğºğ‘ŸOPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle G(r)\rangle, is negative at distances r>0ğ‘Ÿ0italic-r RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0r>0. However reflection positivity is lost during cooling, since cooling affects the quantum structure of the theory leaving only the semiclassical background intact. After cooling one in general obtains positive values for âŸ¨Gâ¢(r)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğºğ‘ŸOPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle G(r)\rangle, apart from those large separations which the cooling procedure has not yet affected.. We compared the results which presented the same value for the internal energy Eğ¸italic-EE which is defined by

div.p: and is proportional to the lattice action. In Fig.Â 3 we show the behavior of the shell correlation versus Eğ¸italic-EE during the three (protracted) coolings for the case of rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr equal to the distance dğ‘‘italic-dd between the centers of the instanton and of the anti-instanton (left) and to the instanton (or anti-instanton) size ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho (right). The three curves fall on top of each other, apart from a small deviation between the Pisa cooling and the other two at the very first (1â€“2) cooling steps, due to (unphysical) finite size effects. Since the shell correlation of the topological charge density is related to the size of the instantons, the conclusion is that the three cooling methods perform equivalently in deforming the size of both the instanton and the anti-instanton in the Iâ€“A pair and in modifying the distance between the two peaks.

The two amounts of cooling are equivalent in the sense explained in the text.

div.p: Using artificial configurations with nonâ€“trivial topology provides interesting suggestions about a cooling procedure, but in real life the cooling must be applied on thermal equilibrium configurations. Among them there are configurations which contain several instanton and anti-instanton bumps, merged in a sea of quantum fluctuations. These configurations can represent as well good testâ€“fields for the different cooling procedures. Their evolution under cooling can be visualized by the distribution of the action density or of the topological charge density. In principle we could expect that the three cooling methods described in SectionÂ 3 make the starting thermalized configuration evolve along different directions. In particular, for a not too protracted cooling, one expects that all the three methods have been able to erase the quantum fluctuations, but the number, type and location of the surviving topological bumps in the cooled configuration can be rather different. In order to check this expectation, it is necessary to find a criterion to make a correspondence between the number of iterations in the standard or Pisa coolings with a Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta parameter for the new cooling. We defined an effective temperature for configurations obtained during the cooling iteration in such a way that the comparison could be made only between configurations at the same temperature. The most natural â€œthermometerâ€ is the internal energy Eğ¸italic-EE, Eq.Â (21), since this is the quantity which is minimized during the cooling procedure.

We put into practice the above considerations in the case of the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model. We generated by Monte Carlo a sample of equilibrium configurations on a 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} lattice at Î²=1.05ğ›½1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05. As in Ref.Â [14], the simulation algorithm is, for every updating step, a mixture of 4 microcanonical updates and 1 over heatâ€“bathÂ [17]. We measured the expectation value of Eğ¸italic-EE on the cooled ensembles obtained by the three cooling methods after several number of iterations (standard and Pisa coolings) and for several values of Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta (new cooling). By comparing the results and imposing that Eğ¸italic-EE be the same, we obtained a correspondence table between the number of cooling iterations for the standard and Pisa coolings with a value of the Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta parameter in the new cooling. We found for instance that for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model at the above values of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta and lattice size, 30 iterations of the standard cooling correspond (in the sense of the average value of Eğ¸italic-EE) to Î´=0.007ğ›¿0.007italic-delta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.007\delta=0.007 for the new cooling and to approximately 33 iterations of the Pisa cooling.

In general the matching between the number of standard and Pisa cooling iterations is not as good as the one obtained between Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta in the new cooling and a fixed number of iterations in the standard (or Pisa) cooling. The reason is that in the second case one can tune a continuous parameter while in the first only integer jumps of the parameter controlling the amount of cooling are allowed. For this reason we have mainly investigated the relation existing between the standard and new coolings. In TableÂ 1 we show the values of Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta (new cooling) found in correspondence to several numbers of iterations of the standard cooling for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model at Î²=1.05ğ›½1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05 on a 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} lattice. Notice that a different correspondence table may be found for other values of Nğ‘italic-NN and Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta.

Using the correspondence table we can directly compare the different coolings. As a first step, we have computed the average values of some physical quantities on samples obtained after applying equivalent amounts of cooling on a set of equilibrium configurations. In Fig.Â 4 we show the results for the lattice topological susceptibility with the standard and new coolings. By using the relation given in TableÂ 1, we report both determinations in terms of the number of standard cooling iterations. It clearly appears that, regarding to the determination of the topological susceptibility, the two cooling techniques are completely equivalent.

div.p: is the lattice Fourier transform of the correlation of two local gaugeâ€“invariant composite operators Piâ¢jâ¢(x)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¥italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)P_{ij}(x) which have been defined in Eq.Â (7) (the subscript â€œconnâ€ means connected Green function). The results for Ï‡msubscriptğœ’mitalic-chi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi_{\rm m} and Î¾G/asubscriptğœ‰ğºğ‘italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a\xi_{G}/a from Fig.Â 5 indicate that in this case the new cooling and the standard cooling show a good agreement, apart from a small discrepancy at large numbers of iterations.

We have also studied the shell correlation of two lattice topological charge density operators, âŸ¨Gâ¢(r)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğºğ‘ŸOPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle{G}(r)\rangle, for r/ağ‘Ÿğ‘italic-r MULOP:divide italic-ar/a going from 0 to 20, after equivalent amounts of the three coolings. In Fig.Â 6 we compare the standard cooling (30 iterations) to the new cooling (Î´=0.007ğ›¿0.007italic-delta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.007\delta=0.007) and the Pisa cooling (33 iterations, Î´Pisa=0.2subscriptğ›¿Pisa0.2italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Pisa POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2\delta_{\rm Pisa}=0.2)333See footnote 2 in SectionÂ 5 about the positivity of âŸ¨Gâ¢(r)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğºğ‘ŸOPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle{G}(r)\rangle after cooling.. The results are in good agreement, although a small deviation can be observed at small distances. The suggestion of this outcome is that the three coolings affect the instanton size distribution in the small distance region in a slightly different way; the effect is however modest.

Next we compared the three coolings on a subset of the aboveâ€“generated thermal equilibrium ensemble for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model. To this aim, we have chosen from the thermal ensemble several configurations showing nonâ€“zero topological charge after 30 iterations of the standard cooling and compared their action density and topological charge density distributions by eye to those of the same configurations cooled by 33 iterations of the Pisa cooling and by the new cooling with Î´=0.007ğ›¿0.007italic-delta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.007\delta=0.007. For all the configurations considered, we observed that the bumps corresponding to instantons and anti-instantons had the same shape, number and location (see Fig.Â 7 for an example).

These considerations provide evidence that the three cooling methods defined in SectionÂ 3 behave essentially in an equivalent way, not only on average, but also configuration by configuration, and that they can be related by a simple correspondence between number of iterations (standard and Pisa coolings) and Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta (new cooling).

We close this Section with some considerations about the usual picture of cooling as a diffusion process. As we pointed out in SectionÂ 3, the parameter Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta in the new cooling behaves, in the continuum limit, like a physical quantity of dimension two. Therefore, indicating with r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{0} the physical scale up to which cooling affects the quantum fluctuations and following Ref.Â [5], we infer that r0âˆÎ´-1/2proportional-tosubscriptğ‘Ÿ0superscriptğ›¿12italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to italic-delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr_{0}\propto\delta^{-1/2} in the continuum limit. On the other hand, the standard cooling is usually believed to act as a diffusion process, so that, if nğ‘›italic-nn is the number of iterations, it should affect fluctuations up to a scale r0âˆn1/2proportional-tosubscriptğ‘Ÿ0superscriptğ‘›12italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr_{0}\propto n^{1/2}. Using the relation found between nğ‘›italic-nn and Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta, we can check both these predictions: indeed we expect that Î´âˆ1/nproportional-toğ›¿1ğ‘›italic-delta RELOP:proportional-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-n\delta\propto 1/n. In Fig.Â 8 we have plotted the function Î´â¢(n)ğ›¿ğ‘›italic-delta OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)\delta(n) given in TableÂ 1, together with a best fit to a function proportional to 1/n1ğ‘›NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-n1/n. For the lattice parameters used in the simulation we see that Î´â¢(n)ğ›¿ğ‘›italic-delta OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)\delta(n) behaves as expected for small values of nğ‘›italic-nn, while the relation Î´âˆ1/nproportional-toğ›¿1ğ‘›italic-delta RELOP:proportional-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-n\delta\propto 1/n breaks down for nâ‰³30-40greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›3040italic-n RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:30 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:40n\gtrsim 30-40, indicating that the picture of the standard cooling as a diffusion process may work well only for moderately small values of nğ‘›italic-nn.

In this Section we apply the new cooling method to the determination of the physical topological susceptibility and compare the results to those from an alternative approach, the field theoretical methodÂ [18] combined with smearingÂ [19]. As for the comparison of the new cooling with the standard and Pisa coolings, we have already shown in the previous Section that they give equivalent results for Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}.

The lattice discretization of the topological charge density and of the topological susceptibility has already been discussed in SectionÂ 2. In the relation existing between the lattice topological susceptibility Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} and the continuum one, Eq.Â (10), Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) indicates the mixings of Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} to operators with the same quantum numbers. More precisely one can write

div.p: The first and second terms in the r.h.s. are the mixings with the trace of the energyâ€“momentum tensor and with the unit operator respectively (â€œnpâ€ means the purely nonâ€“perturbative part of âŸ¨TâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‡OPEN:langle italic-T CLOSE:rangle\langle T\rangle).

The mixing coefficients Aâ¢(Î²)ğ´ğ›½italic-A OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)A(\beta) and Pâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ƒğ›½italic-P OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)P(\beta) as well as the multiplicative renormalization Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) can be calculated in perturbation theory. The perturbative series for Aâ¢(Î²)ğ´ğ›½italic-A OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)A(\beta) starts from the order 1/Î²31superscriptğ›½3NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{3} and arguments can be givenÂ [11] which justify that Aâ¢(Î²)â¢a2â¢âŸ¨TâŸ©npğ´ğ›½superscriptğ‘2subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‡npitalic-A OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:langle italic-T CLOSE:rangle POSTSUBSCRIPT:start np POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA(\beta)\,a^{2}\langle T\rangle_{\rm np} is safely negligible in the scaling window of the simulation. In Ref.Â [20] the perturbative series for Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) has been calculated up to the order 1/Î²21superscriptğ›½2NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{2} and the perturbative series of Pâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ƒğ›½italic-P OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)P(\beta) at the first two nonâ€“zero orders 1/Î²41superscriptğ›½4NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{4} and 1/Î²51superscriptğ›½5NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1/\beta^{5}. On the other hand there are no available perturbative estimates of the Oâ¢(a4)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘4italic-O OPEN:( italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)O(a^{4}) terms in Eq.(24).

However, a more powerful, purely numerical technique can be used to get a nonâ€“perturbative determination of Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and of the whole additive renormalization Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta). This technique is the soâ€“called â€œheating methodâ€Â [21].

The idea of the heating method is to determine the average values of topological quantities on samples of configurations obtained by thermalizing the shortâ€“range fluctuations, which are responsible for the renormalizations, on configurations of well defined topological background. For instance if one applies several thermalization steps at a given value of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta on a configuration containing one discretized instanton of charge Q=1ğ‘„1italic-Q RELOP:equals NUMBER:1Q=1 and measures the average value of QLsuperscriptğ‘„ğ¿italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{L}, then the renormalization constant Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) can be determined as Zâ¢(Î²)=âŸ¨QLâŸ©/Qğ‘ğ›½delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘„ğ¿ğ‘„italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle MULOP:divide italic-QZ(\beta)=\langle Q^{L}\rangle/Q (here âŸ¨â‹…âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©â‹…OPEN:langle MULOP:cdot CLOSE:rangle\langle\cdot\rangle indicates an average in the background of a fixed charge Qğ‘„italic-QQ). Analogously, by thermalizing a trivial configuration (for example a configuration where for all lattice sites xğ‘¥italic-xx, the respective fields are zâ¢(x)=(1,0,0,â€¦)ğ‘§ğ‘¥100â€¦italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, ID:dots CLOSE:)z(x)=(1,0,0,\dots) and Î»Î¼â¢(x)=1subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥1italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\lambda_{\mu}(x)=1) at a given Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta and measuring the average value of Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}, one gets a determination of Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta). In the first case one obtains a nonâ€“perturbative estimate of Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) as long as the MSÂ¯Â¯MSOVERACCENT:overline ARG:start ATOM:MS ARG:end\overline{\hbox{MS}} value of the background topological charge Qğ‘„italic-QQ is chosen (see SectionÂ 2). In the second case the method amounts to impose the requirement that the physical susceptibility Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi vanishes in the absence of instantons.

The heating method has been extensively applied in the following. Once all the renormalization constants are known, the extraction of Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi from Eq.Â (10) is possible and the result is called the field theoretical determination.

div.p: Since the continuum Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi is extracted from the lattice Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} by subtracting the renormalization effects, it happens that, if Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) is a large part of the whole lattice signal and Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) is small, the physical signal for Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi is extracted with very large errors. This is the case when one uses the lattice discretization of Eq.Â (6). However, since both Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) depend on the discretization qLâ¢(x)superscriptğ‘ğ¿ğ‘¥italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q^{L}(x), one can exploit the arbitrariness in the lattice definition and use an improved operator. To this aim, following the idea of Ref.Â [19], already used for the determination of Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi in Yangâ€“Mills theoriesÂ [22], we have used a smeared topological charge density operator, which is built from the original operator qLâ¢(x)superscriptğ‘ğ¿ğ‘¥italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q^{L}(x), defined in Eq.Â (6), by replacing the fields zâ¢(x)ğ‘§ğ‘¥italic-z OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)z(x) and Î»Î¼â¢(x)subscriptğœ†ğœ‡ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\lambda_{\mu}(x) with

A similar behavior has been observed in Yangâ€“Mills theoriesÂ [23].. The smearing can be iterated at will by defining the nğ‘›italic-nnâ€“th level of smeared fields from the (n-1)ğ‘›1OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(n-1)â€“th level in an analogous fashion as shown in Eq.Â (25). For each level of smearing a relation like Eq.Â (10) holds although Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) change. Using smeared operators these renormalization constants get closer to 1 and 0, respectively, as the smearing level increases, thus allowing a much more precise determination of Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi.

We performed a numerical simulation for the CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} model at several values of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta and Lğ¿italic-LL. We used the same updating algorithm of the previous Section. For most simulations we collected 100K equilibrium configurations after discarding 10K configurations to allow thermalization. The successive equilibrium configurations were decorrelated by 10 updating steps. By averaging on the thermal equilibrium ensemble we determined the unsmeared lattice topological susceptibility Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} and the smeared ones, Ï‡smearLsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿smearitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start smear POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\mathrm{smear}}, for 1 to 10 smearing levels. These results, together with Zâ¢(Î²)ğ‘ğ›½italic-Z OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)Z(\beta) and Mâ¢(Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½italic-M OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)M(\beta) coming from the heating method, allow to extract a2â¢Ï‡superscriptğ‘2ğœ’italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chia^{2}\chi from Eq.Â (10).

Every 50 updating steps we have also applied the new cooling method at several values of the Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta parameter ranging from 0.3 to 5Ã—10-45superscript104NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{-4}. Since cooling eliminates the shortâ€“distance fluctuations, the value of Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} after cooling, hereafter called Ï‡coolLsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\mathrm{cool}}, can be written as in Eq.Â (10) with Zâ‰ˆ1ğ‘1italic-Z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1Z\approx 1 and Mâ‰ˆ0ğ‘€0italic-M RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0M\approx 0 if the cooling has been protracted enough. Hence it should provide directly a2â¢Ï‡superscriptğ‘2ğœ’italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chia^{2}\chi. Consistency requires that the cooling and the field theoretical methods provide the same result.

Data points have been slightly shifted along the Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta axis for the sake of readability.

div.p: The summary of the performed simulations is presented in TableÂ 2. In Fig.Â 9 we show the results for Ï‡coolLsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\rm cool} from the new cooling at several values for the Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta parameter at Î²=0.70ğ›½0.70italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70\beta=0.70 on a 242superscript242NUMBER:24 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end24^{2} lattice. We interpret the behavior under the new cooling in the following way: as Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta decreases, the cooling erases an even larger amount of quantum fluctuations thus bringing Ï‡coolLsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\rm cool} to a maximum. Afterwards, for too small values of Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta, the cooling begins to affect also the topological fluctuations and part of the topological signal gets lost. These considerations suggest that a convenient choice of the Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta parameter may be around the value for which Ï‡coolLsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\rm cool} reaches the maximum. At this value of Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta we then assume that Zâ‰ˆ1ğ‘1italic-Z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1Z\approx 1 and Mâ‰ˆ0ğ‘€0italic-M RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0M\approx 0. The choice of a smaller value for Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta would not be dramatically dangerous, but would push the scaling region towards larger values of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta.

In TableÂ 3 we summarize the results for Ï‡Lsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{L} and for Î¾G2â¢Ï‡superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğº2ğœ’italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi obtained for CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} by the field theoretical method combined with smearing (0, 5 and 10 levels). In TableÂ 4 the results for Ï‡coolLsubscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ¿coolitalic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cool POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\chi^{L}_{\mathrm{cool}} and Î¾G2â¢Ï‡subscriptsuperscriptğœ‰2ğºğœ’italic-xi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi^{2}_{G}\,\chi obtained by the new cooling method for Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta around the peak value (see Fig.Â 9 for Î²=0.70ğ›½0.70italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70\beta=0.70) are shown. Fig.Â 10 displays the scaling of Î¾G2â¢Ï‡superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğº2ğœ’italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi for the cases of 0, 5 and 10 smearing levels and the field theoretical method (left) and with the new cooling method for Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta=0.0100, 0.0050, 0.0025 (right). From this figure we see that there is practically no dependence on the smearing level, although error bars strongly decrease with the number of smearing levels. As for the cooling method, we see that there is a satisfying consistence among the results for the different values of Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta and also between these results and those from the field theoretical method.

The study of the topological properties of the vacuum of a field theory simulated on a lattice is made difficult by the presence of quantum fluctuations which hinder the extraction of the relevant physical information. Among other methods, cooling has been proposed as a technique to wash out such fluctuations and reveal the topological background of any single field configuration. In the present paper we have made a comparison among three different cooling methods using as testâ€“field the 2d CPN-1ğ‘1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{N-1} model defined in SectionÂ 2.

The three cooling methods under study have been defined in SectionÂ 3. They are: the standard cooling (a local minimization of the Euclidean lattice action), the Pisa cooling (the same but with local minimizations constrained to be smaller than a given bound) and a new cooling (recently introduced in Ref.Â [5]) where the local minimizations are accepted only if they are larger than a given bound.

Firstly, we have studied the performance of the three coolings on classical nonâ€“equi-librium configurations representing 1â€“instanton solutions and instantonâ€“anti-instanton pairs. We have placed one such object on the lattice and have performed a series of cooling iterations in order to measure several physical (topological and nonâ€“topological) observables. In all situations the three coolings have yielded the same result â€”see Figs.Â 2 andÂ 3.

After these results, we have assumed that the three cooling methods are equivalent and that a correspondence can be established between them in the sense that a given number of iterations of the Pisa or the standard coolings corresponds to a precise value for the bound in the new cooling if the value of the energy Eğ¸italic-EE, Eq.Â (21), is the same after applying the coolings. This correspondence has been used in the subsequent investigation and, for the CP33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} model at Î²=1.05ğ›½1.05italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.05\beta=1.05 on a 762superscript762NUMBER:76 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end76^{2} lattice, it is shown in TableÂ 1.

We have studied the performance of the cooling methods on a set of equilibrium configurations obtained after a Monte Carlo simulation. On these thermalized configurations we have first extracted several physical quantities after applying cooling: the lattice topological susceptibility is the same when equivalent amounts of cooling, in the sense of TableÂ 1, are applied â€”see Fig.Â 4. The same happens for the magnetic susceptibility and for the correlation length as far as the cooling iteration is not protracted too much â€”see Fig.Â 5. The same agreement is seen for the shell correlation function âŸ¨Gâ¢(r)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğºğ‘ŸOPEN:langle italic-G OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle G(r)\rangle if r/ağ‘Ÿğ‘italic-r MULOP:divide italic-ar/a is large enough â€”see Fig.Â 6. Then we have peered the action density and the topological charge density distributions obtained with the application of equivalent amounts of cooling, in the sense of TableÂ 1. In all cases we have again obtained completely analogous distributions â€”see Fig.Â 7 for an example. These results altogether strongly suggest that the three cooling methods, although different in the procedure, behave equivalently.

By using the correspondence given in TableÂ 1 we have tested the picture of cooling as a diffusion process. For the lattice parameters used in this analysis, this picture works well only for a moderately small number of iterations (nâ‰²40less-than-or-similar-toğ‘›40italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:40n\lesssim 40).

Finally we have compared the results obtained for the topological susceptibility in the CP99FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9} model by the new cooling method with those extracted from a wellâ€“tested method: the soâ€“called field theoretical method improved with smearing. In TablesÂ 3 andÂ 4 we give the results for the quantity Î¾G2â¢Ï‡superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğº2ğœ’italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi. They agree fairly well among them, see Fig.Â 10, and also with the large Nğ‘italic-NN estimateÂ [24] which provides Î¾G2â¢Ï‡=153superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğº2ğœ’153italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-chi RELOP:equals NUMBER:153\xi_{G}^{2}\,\chi=153 up to order Oâ¢(1/N2)ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘2italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)O(1/N^{2}).

We used the standard action both to generate thermal equilibrium configurations in Monte Carlo simulations and during the cooling procedure. We expect that the above results concerning the equivalence between the different cooling techniques should not depend strongly on the action used during cooling. However the comparison of the three cooling techniques by using different lattice actions is worth to be pursued in a future work.
